prescription_defaults.notes: Tendon glides + open/close pulses + wrist circles. Goal: warmth and readiness, not pump. Stay easy.

exercises.name: Wrist Extensor Eccentrics

prescription_defaults.notes: Tempo: 3-1-1.

exercises.description: Eccentric wrist extensor exercise targeting extensor carpi radialis and digitorum. Primary prevention and treatment for lateral epicondylitis in climbers. Slow lowering phase stimulates tendon remodeling.
cues: Forearm rested on bench, wrist hanging off edge in pronation
Use other hand to raise wrist to top position
Lower slowly over 3-4 seconds — this is the key phase
Lead with knuckles, no finger curling to cheat
Pain-free range only — mild discomfort acceptable

exercises.name: Band External Rotation
exercises.description: Rotator cuff strengthening via band external rotation. Targets infraspinatus and teres minor to counterbalance climbing's pull-dominant shoulder pattern. Standard prehab for all climbing levels (Hörst, Dr. Vagy, Mend Colorado).
cues: Elbow tucked at side, bent to 90°
Place small towel under arm for better infraspinatus isolation
Rotate forearm outward — elbow stays fixed at ribs
Slow and controlled 15-20 reps, light band only
If it feels hard, use lighter band — rotator cuff is endurance, not power

prescription_defaults.notes: Short controlled pulls, not max.

exercises.name: Easy Dead Hangs (Warm-up)

prescription_defaults.notes: Very easy intensity.

exercises.description: Low-intensity dead hangs used as warm-up or tendon conditioning. Builds blood flow and prepares fingers without fatigue.
cues: Use large comfortable edge
Shoulders engaged, body still
Conversational effort (RPE 4-5)
Breathe normally
Perfect for daily use or rehab

exercises.name: Max Hang (5s)
exercises.description: Short-duration maximum-weight hangs for peak neural recruitment and finger flexor strength (López/Hörst MaxHangs MAW short variant).
cues: Choose edge/weight you can hold 7-8s max
Hang exactly 5s — not to failure
Shoulders engaged, elbows slightly forward
Add weight in 2.5-5kg increments
Fully warmed up (15-20 min progressive)

exercises.name: Max Hang (7s)
exercises.description: 7-second near-maximal hangs for maximum finger strength and neural drive (Hörst/López protocol).
cues: Edge/weight you can hold exactly 10s max
Hang precisely 7 seconds
Shoulders packed, body completely still
53-second rest optimizes PCr recovery
Last set should be very hard but perfect form

exercises.name: Bechtel 3-6-9 Ladder

prescription_defaults.notes: Progressive ladder WITHIN each set: 3s → rest 10-30s → 6s → rest → 9s (optional 12s). 3-5 full ladders per grip position.

exercises.description: Steve Bechtel’s 3-6-9 Ladders: progressive duration hangs within each set to build maximum finger strength with built-in recovery.
cues: Edge you can hold 8-12s max
3s → short rest → 6s → short rest → 9s (opt 12s)
Adjust inter-hang rest based on recovery
3-5 full ladders per grip (half-crimp, open, pinch)
3-5 min rest between full ladder sets

exercises.name: Hangboard Repeaters 7/3 (Strength-Endurance)

prescription_defaults.notes: Aim ~60–75% max hang load; stop before form breaks. Protocol: 7s_on/3s_off.

exercises.description: Classic Anderson Brothers / Hörst repeater protocol for finger strength-endurance: trains anaerobic capacity and lactate tolerance with 42s TUT per set.
cues: 60-80% MVC (finish all 6 reps but pumped)
Strict 7s on / 3s off timing
Shoulders active, no dead hang
Half-crimp primary, alternate grips across sets
If you drop before rep 6, reduce load

exercises.name: Hörst 7-53 Protocol

prescription_defaults.notes: 90-95% intensity. Each set = 3 hangs (7s on / 53s off). 3 min between sets. Hörst signature protocol.

exercises.description: The signature Hörst 7-53 protocol builds maximum finger strength and neural drive through short, near-maximal isometric hangs with precise phosphocreatine recovery timing.
cues: Choose edge/weight you can hold exactly 10s max
Hang exactly 7s (not to failure)
Shoulders packed, body still, no kipping
53s rest = full PCr resynthesis
Last set should feel very hard but form perfect

exercises.name: Repeater Hang 15/15 (IntHangs)

prescription_defaults.notes: 4-5 reps, 7-10s work. Eva López IntHangs standard protocol.

exercises.description: Eva López Intermittent Hangs (IntHangs) protocol for strength-endurance: medium intensity repeated hangs with short rest.
cues: Strict timing: 10s on / 15s off
Half-crimp primary
Finish all reps with good form
TUT per set ~40-50s

exercises.name: Density Hangs (Tyler Nelson)

prescription_defaults.notes: 20-40s to near-failure. Open-hand preferred.

exercises.description: Tyler Nelson’s Density Hangs protocol for tendon hypertrophy, stress-shielding and forearm muscle density via long-duration near-failure hangs.
cues: Open-hand grip preferred
Hang 20-40s to ~95% RPE (near failure)
2-3 reps per grip, 3-5 min rest
Choose edge you can hold 20-45s bodyweight
Elbows extended, focus on tendon health

exercises.name: Long Duration Hang (Tendon Health)

prescription_defaults.notes: Large edge (25-35mm). 30-45s hangs. Low intensity, focus on tissue loading and injury prevention.

exercises.description: Long-duration hangs (30+ seconds) at moderate intensity for tendon conditioning, injury prevention and structural adaptation (Lattice protocol).
cues: Large comfortable hold
30-70% intensity (conversational)
Continuous hang, no reps
90s-2min rest between sets
Excellent for warm-up or rehab

exercises.name: Minimum Edge Hang (MED)

prescription_defaults.notes: Bodyweight only. Minimum edge = smallest edge you can hold for 15s at bodyweight. 3 min rest between hangs, 5 min between full sets.

exercises.description: Minimum Edge (MED) protocol for structural tendon adaptation and small-edge specificity. Hang exactly 12 seconds on the smallest edge you can hold for ~15 seconds bodyweight only.
cues: Find edge you can barely hold 15s max
Hang precisely 12s (3s safety margin)
Full bodyweight — no added load
Shoulders packed, body still
Progress by reducing edge depth week-to-week

exercises.name: Pinch Block Training

prescription_defaults.notes: Loadable pinch block. Progress via added weight. Full thumb wrap.

exercises.description: Hörst pinch-grip repeater training to strengthen thumb-lock and closed-crimp positions using a pinch block.
cues: Use Tension Block or Lattice Quad
7-second hangs strict timing
6 reps per hand per set
Add weight via loading pin
Thumb fully locked

exercises.name: One-Arm Hang (Assisted)

prescription_defaults.notes: One arm with pulley or band assistance. 20mm edge. Half crimp. Advanced only.

exercises.description: Advanced one-arm hang protocol (Cameron Hörst) for unilateral finger strength using assistance to reduce bodyweight.
cues: Use pulley system or band
5-10 second hangs
Prevent body spinning
Shoulder stable and packed
Progress by reducing assistance

exercises.name: López Submaximal Hangs

prescription_defaults.notes: 30-40% max load. High volume, low intensity. Eva López protocol for tendon conditioning.

exercises.description: Eva López Submaximal Hangs for strength-endurance and aerobic power: long hangs at 55-85% MVC with progressive rest reduction.
cues: Single continuous hang 20-45s per set
Near-failure at end of TUT
Rest starts long (180s) and decreases to 30s over weeks
Half-crimp primary
Excellent for hypertrophy without max intensity

exercises.name: Critical Force Test

prescription_defaults.notes: 7s on / 3s off to failure at fixed load. Determines aerobic threshold of forearm.

exercises.description: Scientific 3-stage all-out test to determine finger flexor critical force (CF) and W' (Giles et al. / Lattice).
cues: Requires force gauge (Tindeq)
Stage 1: 80% MVC to failure
Stage 2: 60% MVC immediately
Stage 3: 45% MVC immediately
Record time to failure each stage

exercises.name: Maximum Effort Duration Test (MED)

prescription_defaults.notes: Hang at 45% bodyweight until failure. Record total seconds.

exercises.description: Lattice Maximum Effort Duration test: single continuous hang at 45% MVC to failure to assess finger endurance capacity.
cues: 45% of MVC-7
Continuous hang to absolute failure
Record exact seconds
Use for tracking endurance progress
Typically 60-300s for trained climbers

exercises.name: ARC / Easy Volume (Aerobic Endurance)

prescription_defaults.notes: Very low pump. Continuous movement. If pump rises, downgrade.

exercises.description: ARC (Aerobic Restoration and Capillarization) at easy grade on bouldering wall, spray wall or board. Builds capillary density and forearm aerobic capacity through sustained low-intensity climbing. The defining constraint of ARC is zero pump — any forearm fatigue means the grade is too high. (Lattice: 2/10 RPE for 10-30+ min continuous)
cues: Zero pump is the goal — if forearm starts to fill, step off and rest or switch to easier holds
Hands near heart level to optimize blood flow and reduce cardiovascular strain
Grade 4-5 below boulder onsight — should feel embarrassingly easy
Move continuously: traverses, up-downs, linking easy problems. Stop = failed set
Breathing stays conversational throughout — you should be able to talk normally

exercises.name: Technique Boulder Drills (Footwork / Efficiency)

prescription_defaults.notes: Silent feet, no readjust, hip-in, breathing. Keep it easy.

exercises.description: Free-form technique drill session at the gym: silent feet, no readjust, hip engagement, breathing control. Grade kept well below max to allow movement quality focus.
cues: Silent feet: place feet without sound, feel the hold before weighting
No readjust: commit to each foot placement first time
Hip engagement: actively twist hips toward wall on steep terrain
Breathing: exhale on hard moves, never hold breath
Grade should feel easy — this is skill work, not fitness work

exercises.name: Split Squat (Single-leg)
exercises.description: Bulgarian or rear-foot-elevated split squat. Unilateral lower body strength targeting quad, glute, and hip stability — directly transfers to high-stepping and heel hook loading. One of the few lower body exercises consistently recommended across climbing coaches.
cues: Back foot elevated on bench or box at knee height
Front foot far enough forward that shin stays vertical at bottom
Knee tracks over second toe throughout — no valgus collapse
Torso upright or slight forward lean, core engaged
Full range: back knee approaches but does not touch floor
3-second eccentric lower for maximum tendon adaptation

exercises.name: Pull-up
exercises.description: Foundational pull-muscle exercise for climbers. Trains latissimus dorsi, biceps, and scapular stabilizers through full range of motion. Prerequisite for all advanced pulling work — must be able to do 10+ strict reps before progressing to weighted or one-arm variations. (Hörst, Lattice, The Climbing Doctor)
cues: Dead hang start — full elbow extension, shoulders active not passive
Pull elbows DOWN toward pockets, not arms toward bar
Lead with chest, chin clears bar at top
Scapulae depress and retract as you pull — no shrugging
Controlled 2-3s lowering — no dropping

exercises.name: Chin-up
exercises.description: Supinated-grip pull-up (palms toward face). Targets biceps and lats with strong forearm flexor involvement. Higher biceps activation than pronated pullup, making it a useful complement for climbers who lack elbow flexor strength relative to lat strength.
cues: Shoulders packed before pulling: depress and retract scapulae
Initiate movement by driving elbows down toward hips, not by shrugging
Chin clearly over bar at top — no neck craning
Full extension at bottom: straight arms before each rep
3-second eccentric lower — do not drop
Quality over quantity: stop set when form breaks

exercises.name: Scapular Pull-up
exercises.description: Isometric and dynamic scapular depression / retraction drill from a dead hang. Activates lower trapezius and serratus anterior without elbow flexion. Critical for shoulder health in climbers — prevents impingement, builds the foundation for all pulling movements. Hörst describes it as 'The Best Climbing Exercise You're Not Doing'.
cues: Start in dead hang: arms fully extended, shoulders passively elevated
With straight arms only: pull shoulders down and back (do NOT bend elbows)
Feel lower trapezius and lats engage — chest rises slightly toward bar
Hold 2 seconds at top, then slowly return to passive hang
Zero elbow bend throughout — if elbows bend, it has become a pullup
Do before every climbing session as part of warm-up

exercises.name: Inverted Row

prescription_defaults.notes: Rings, low bar, or TRX. Easier than pullup. Great for shoulder health.

exercises.description: Horizontal pull from below a bar or rings with body at an angle. Targets rhomboids, mid-traps, and rear deltoids — antagonist musculature to climbing's dominant vertical pull pattern. Reduces shoulder injury risk. Angle of body controls difficulty: more horizontal = harder.
cues: Body forms a straight line from heels to shoulders — engage core and glutes
Initiate by retracting scapulae before bending elbows
Pull bar or rings to lower sternum / upper abdomen — not chin
Elbows stay close to body at roughly 45° flare
Full extension at bottom before next rep
To increase difficulty: raise feet, use rings, add pause at top

exercises.name: Band-assisted Pull-up
exercises.description: Standard pronated pullup with a resistance band looped over the bar for assistance. Removes a percentage of bodyweight to allow proper pullup mechanics for climbers not yet able to do 3+ unassisted reps. Progressive: move to thinner bands as strength builds.
cues: Knee or foot in band — knee in band = more stable, foot in band = more authentic movement
Same cues as standard pullup: packed shoulders, elbows driving down
Choose band that allows 5-8 clean reps — if 10+ feels easy, use thinner band
Eccentric still matters: control the lowering phase even with band assistance
Goal: eliminate band entirely. Transition test: can you do 3 unassisted reps?

exercises.name: Dip

prescription_defaults.notes: Can use parallel bars or rings.

exercises.description: Antagonist push exercise for climbers targeting triceps, pectorals, and anterior deltoid. Counterbalances the pull-dominant climbing pattern. Essential for elbow health and pressing strength. (Hörst antagonist training)
cues: Slight forward lean for chest emphasis, upright for triceps
Lower until upper arms are parallel to floor — no deeper
Keep shoulders away from ears throughout
Controlled lowering 2s, no bouncing at bottom
Full lockout at top without hyperextending elbows

exercises.name: Push-up
exercises.description: Standard horizontal push-up. Primary antagonist pressing movement for climbers — counterbalances the dominant pulling and internal rotation load. Targets pectorals, anterior deltoid, triceps, and serratus anterior. Accessible, zero-equipment, foundational.
cues: Hands shoulder-width or slightly wider, fingers spread and gripping the floor
Body forms a single rigid plank: core, glutes, quads all engaged
Elbows at 45° flare from torso — not flared wide, not pinned in
Lower chest to 1-2 cm from floor — full range of motion
Push floor away on the way up: protract scapulae at the top
Quality: 3-second lower. If reps degrade to half-ROM, stop the set

exercises.name: Pike Push-up
exercises.description: Vertical push-up pattern from a pike (inverted-V) body position — hip hinge with hands and feet on floor, head below hips. Emphasises anterior deltoid and triceps more than horizontal pushup. Progression toward handstand pushup; directly trains overhead pressing strength for manteling.
cues: Start in downward-dog position: hips high, arms and legs straight
Lower crown of head toward the floor between hands
Elbows flare naturally outward — allow this in the pike position
Push back to full arm extension, maintaining hip elevation throughout
Walk feet closer to hands for more vertical load (harder); further away for easier
If wrists are uncomfortable, use push-up handles or fists

exercises.name: Bench Press
exercises.description: Horizontal barbell or dumbbell pressing. Comprehensive horizontal push pattern targeting pectorals, anterior deltoid, and triceps. Most load-measurable of all pressing movements, making progressive overload easy to track. Useful for climbers needing significant upper-body push antagonist work to address strength imbalances.
cues: Feet flat on floor, slight arch in lower back — retract and depress scapulae against bench
Grip width: slightly outside shoulder width — wrists stacked over elbows at bottom
Lower bar to lower sternum with control — 3-second eccentric
Drive feet through floor and squeeze glutes on the press
Elbows at 45-75° flare — avoid flaring fully to protect shoulder
Dumbbells: allow natural arc rather than forcing a straight bar path

exercises.name: Overhead Press
exercises.description: Vertical pressing pattern (barbell or dumbbell). Targets anterior/medial deltoid and triceps. Trains the overhead position climbers need for manteling and high-ball pressing. Addresses the deltoid imbalance common in climbers who over-train vertical pull.
cues: Standing: feet shoulder-width, slight core brace — do not hyperextend lower back
Bar starts at upper chest / collarbone level, elbows slightly in front of bar
Press directly overhead — bar travels in a slight arc around the face
Finish with bar over mid-foot and ears visible in front of upper arm
Lower with control: 3-second eccentric
Seated dumbbell variation is shoulder-health-friendly alternative if bar feels uncomfortable

exercises.name: Plank
exercises.description: Foundational anti-extension isometric. Develops total-body tension directly transferable to steep climbing. Builds the ability to keep hips close to the wall and transfer force between arms and feet. (Horst plank sequence; inSPIRE Rock core guide)
cues: Neutral spine — no hip sag and no piking up
Actively squeeze glutes and quads to close hips toward shoulders
Ears aligned with shoulders, gaze toward floor
Breathe steadily — do not hold breath
Progress by moving elbows forward past shoulder line for longer lever

exercises.name: Hollow Body Hold
exercises.description: Gymnastic full-body tension hold pressing lower back into the floor to activate deep transverse abdominis. Directly trains the body tension required to keep feet on steep terrain and resist barn-dooring. (Horst; Lattice conditioning)
cues: Lower back must stay in contact with the floor throughout — if it lifts, raise legs higher
Arms extended overhead increases the lever; bend them to regress
Breathe in short controlled pulses — never hold breath
Progress by gradually lowering legs toward the floor as strength builds
Stop the set the moment lower back lifts — form over duration

exercises.name: L-Sit (Floor)

prescription_defaults.notes: Parallettes removed in v1; floor variant only.

exercises.description: Isometric compression hold building hip flexor and deep core strength. Prerequisite for bat hangs, high-step compression and heel hook loading on steep terrain. Floor variant — no parallettes required. (climbing.com front lever guide; Horst conditioning)
cues: Shoulders depressed and retracted — create space between ears and shoulders
Push firmly through palms and fully extend elbows
Legs straight and together, held parallel to floor
If too hard: tuck-sit (bent knees) first, then one leg extended
Engage quads aggressively — soft legs kill the position

exercises.name: Thoracic & Shoulder Mobility Flow

prescription_defaults.notes: Dynamic flow: thoracic rotations, arm circles, scapular CARs. No static stretching.

exercises.description: Thoracic spine and shoulder mobility flow — combining thoracic CARs (controlled articular rotations), cat-cow, thread-the-needle, and open-book rotations. Targets the thoracic extension and rotation deficit common in climbers from sustained forward-flexed postures on overhanging walls. 5 minutes pre-session for optimal shoulder range.
cues: Cat-cow: 10 slow cycles — fully exhale at the top of cat, fully inhale at cow
Thread-the-needle: from all-fours, slide one arm under body and rotate, hold 5s each side × 5
Open-book: side-lying, top arm sweeps open while lower arm stays, eyes follow the hand
T-spine CARs: seated on heels, hands behind head, rotate thorax maximally — 5 each direction
Do not force range: the goal is controlled quality rotation, not maximum stretch

prescription_defaults.notes: Light jogging in place + arm swings.

exercises.name: Campus Board Ladders (Controlled)

prescription_defaults.notes: Controlled ladders, avoid cutting feet.

exercises.description: Foot-on campus board laddering on larger rungs for beginners and intermediate climbers. Trains contact strength and RFD with reduced injury risk. Named after Wolfgang Güllich's original campus board. Entry point to campus training per Hörst: at minimum 2 years experience required.
cues: Feet on wall or holds — use them to stay safe and controlled
Alternate hands smoothly one rung at a time, no skipping
Short, quick movements — eliminate dead time between moves
Engaged shoulders: slightly bent elbows, chest puffed, no shrugging
Stop when form degrades — quality over volume

exercises.name: Campus Laddering (Feet Off)

prescription_defaults.notes: Half crimp. No skipping rungs. Sprint speed. Stop when speed drops.

exercises.description: Footless campus board laddering — the core campus training exercise. Develops contact strength (RFD) and explosive finger flexor recruitment. Short reach movements train finger speed; larger rung skips train arm power. (Hörst, Gresham: intermediate-advanced only, 5.12+/V6+ minimum)
cues: Start hanging both hands from bottom rung, elbows slightly bent
Alternate hands in a sprint — minimize contact time on each rung
Keep reaches short to target finger contact strength, not arm power
Chest puffed, shoulders engaged — never shrugged or passive
Stop at first sign of form breakdown — never full crimp

exercises.name: Campus Laddering (Feet On Wall)

prescription_defaults.notes: Feet on wall for assistance. Good intermediate progression. Focus on contact quality.

exercises.description: Campus board laddering with feet on wall — intermediate progression between foot-on and full footless campus. Reduces load on fingers/tendons while preserving the contact strength stimulus. Ideal entry into campus training. (Hörst, Gresham)
cues: Light foot contact only — weight primarily through arms
Same arm pattern as footless: alternating, quick, short reaches
Gradually reduce foot contribution as strength improves
Focus on explosive hand placement, not foot reliance
Half-crimp grip unless specifically training open-hand

exercises.name: Campus Bumps (Touch-and-Go)

prescription_defaults.notes: Touch-and-go on higher rung, one arm at a time. Focus explosive contact.

exercises.description: One-arm bump sequence on campus board. One hand stays on lower rung while the other bumps as high as possible in rapid succession. Trains unilateral contact strength and deep lock-off simultaneously. Higher RFD stimulus than two-arm laddering. (Hörst, Gresham)
cues: Lower hand locked, upper hand bumps high repeatedly without touching
Go for maximum height per bump — speed and reach combined
Lock-off with lower arm while upper arm catches each bump
Alternate leading hand between sets
3 sets per side, 2-3 min rest — quality over speed

exercises.name: Campus Double Dyno

prescription_defaults.notes: Advanced only. 5+ years climbing minimum. Double dyno on campus. Full rest between sets.

exercises.description: Campus board double dyno — both hands release and re-catch simultaneously. Maximum RFD stimulus and coordination demand. Hörst: not recommended until 7b+/V9+ and 5+ years experience. Highest injury risk of all campus exercises. (Hörst, Gresham)
cues: Start mid-board both hands on same rung
Drop to lower rung absorbing with slightly bent elbows — no straight-arm catch
Immediately explode back upward to original rung
Chest up, shoulders engaged throughout the catch
If you miss or straight-arm catch — stop immediately

exercises.name: Limit Bouldering (Deadpoint/Latching Focus)

prescription_defaults.notes: 3-7 moves at limit. Focus deadpoint and latching. Full rest. Stop when quality drops.

exercises.description: Max-intensity bouldering at or near limit grade for power and technique integration. The most sport-specific way to train power. Problems should be 1-5 moves, requiring near-maximal effort on each attempt. (Hörst, Lattice — primary strength phase exercise)
cues: Problems at ~1-2 moves above flash level
Full rest between attempts: 3-5 min minimum
Focus on specific crux sequences, not volume
Visualize and rest — quality attempts only
Stop session if power clearly dropping

exercises.name: Board Limit Boulders (Kilter/Moon/Tension)

prescription_defaults.notes: Also works on Moon Board, Tension Board. 3-5 attempts per problem, full rest between.

exercises.description: Limit bouldering on Kilter Board, Moonboard, or training board. Structured overhanging training with graded problems for quantifiable power development. Board climbing allows repeatable, measurable progress on specific movement patterns. (Lattice, Hörst board training protocols)
cues: Choose problems at limit: ~1-3 move failures expected
Board angle: increase for more power emphasis
Track attempts and progress per problem number
Open-hand or half-crimp; full-crimp only if required by problem
3-5 attempts max per problem before moving on

exercises.name: Explosive Pull-ups (Power)

prescription_defaults.notes: Explosive pull, hands leave the bar. Full rest. Quality over quantity.

exercises.description: Explosive pull-ups with maximum velocity intent. Trains rate of force development in pull muscles — directly transfers to latching dynamic moves. Key distinction from weighted pull-ups: speed is the load. (Lattice, Hörst power training)
cues: Pull as fast as possible — get chest to bar
Intention is speed, not height of chin
Full dead hang reset between reps — no kipping
3-5 reps max per set while velocity is maintained
If reps slow down — rest longer or end set

exercises.name: 4x4 Bouldering (Power-Endurance)

prescription_defaults.notes: Choose grade where you fail on rep 3-4. Not rep 1-2 (too hard) or complete all 4 easily (too easy).

exercises.description: 4x4 bouldering: 4 problems climbed back-to-back x 4 rounds. Classic power endurance protocol combining anaerobic capacity with skill. Problems at 60-70% max effort for sustainable volume. (Hörst Training for Climbing, widely used in Lattice protocols)
cues: Problems at comfortable flash level — not limit
Rest 3-4 min between rounds, no rest between problems in set
Maintain consistent movement quality across all 4 rounds
Deep pump expected by round 3-4 — breathe through it
Reduce grade if unable to finish all 4 problems in a round

exercises.name: Linked Boulders (No Pause)

prescription_defaults.notes: Link 3-5 boulders without pause. Moderate grade. Rest fully between sets.

exercises.description: Multiple boulder problems linked together without rest. Sustained power endurance training combining intensity and volume. Length: 6-10 problems per link. (Hörst, Lattice power endurance phase)
cues: Choose problems just below flash level for each
Move directly from top of one to base of next
Aim for 8-12 total hard moves per link
Log grade sequence to repeat and progress
Rest 4-5 min between full link circuits

exercises.name: Route Intervals (Timed Rest)

prescription_defaults.notes: Climb route sections with timed rest. Grade 1-2 below onsight. Focus sustained effort.

exercises.description: Route climbing intervals on rope — repeated ascents of the same route with timed rest. Develops sport-specific power endurance and route reading efficiency. (Hörst threshold training, Lattice route intervals protocol)
cues: Route at ~80% max: should pump but not fail
Rest equal to or less than climb time between reps
Focus on efficient movement and resting on route
Log time per ascent to track improvement
3-5 intervals per session, progressive overload via rest reduction

exercises.name: ARC Training (Continuous Low Intensity)

prescription_defaults.notes: Well below onsight grade. Zero pump. If you feel pump, go easier.

exercises.description: Classic ARC (Aerobic Restoration and Capillarization) on roped wall or bouldering. 20 minutes of genuinely continuous easy movement at 2/10 RPE. Primary adaptation target is capillary density and forearm aerobic enzyme activity — the foundation of route climbing endurance. Distinguished from gym_arc_easy_volume by longer set duration and route-style movement. (Lattice, Hörst, Gresham — universal aerobic base protocol)
cues: Find the grade where you feel nothing in your forearms — this is your ARC grade today
20 continuous minutes: no rests, no shaking out, no sitting on holds
If pump builds at any point, immediately downclimb or traverse to easier terrain
Eyes and mind can wander — ARC should be so easy it is almost boring
After the set, hold arms above heart for 10-15s then shake out to clear blood

exercises.name: Threshold Climbing (Sustained Sub-Onsight)

prescription_defaults.notes: Just below onsight grade. Sustained effort. Moderate pump acceptable.

exercises.description: Sustained sub-onsight climbing on routes at moderate pump. Works the aerobic/anaerobic threshold — the highest intensity maintainable aerobically. Lead route setting at 1 grade below onsight level. Moderate pump acceptable and expected; deep forearm failure is too hard. 2:1 work:rest ratio for route climbing. (Hörst threshold endurance; Gresham training bible 2:1 intervals)
cues: Grade: 1 letter grade below your lead onsight — should feel hard but manageable
RPE 7-8/10 on the wall. Moderate pump is acceptable; cannot-hold-on pump = too hard
120s per set: not a route lap, it's a timed effort. If route ends before 120s, downclimb
60s rest: arms down, shake out actively, breathe. Not a full recovery — that is intentional
6 sets total. Sets 5-6 will feel harder — that metabolic accumulation is the training stimulus

exercises.name: Continuity Climbing (Ultra-Easy Volume)

prescription_defaults.notes: Grade VERY far below onsight (Lattice: 4-6 letter grades). 5 min climbing / 3 min rest. Must feel conversational — if any pump builds you are too hard. Lattice Continuity 5x3 protocol.

exercises.description: Lattice Continuity protocol: 5 min climbing / 3 min rest. Grade is very far below onsight — the defining feature of continuity versus threshold is the absence of any pump. The 5-minute round targets aerobic base without crossing into anaerobic territory. Boulderers can do this on a spray wall or bouldering wall at a very easy grade. (Lattice Training Continuity 5×3 protocol; Tom Randall)
cues: Grade must be 4-6 letter grades below onsight — literally no effort should register in the forearms
5 minutes continuous, zero rest mid-set. If you need to rest, the grade is too hard
3 min rest: enough to fully clear metabolic products before the next set
Boulderers: use the spray wall or traverse at a grade where top moves feel like warm-up
After 4-6 weeks of continuity, transition to ARC for longer continuous sets

exercises.name: Easy Route Laps (Recovery)

prescription_defaults.notes: Easy route laps, ~10 min per lap. Focus recovery, blood flow, movement quality. Grade at least 3 below onsight.

exercises.description: Repeated laps on easy gym routes for active recovery and blood flow. Grade is 3+ below onsight. Not an endurance training stimulus — it is a recovery activity that maintains movement quality and promotes aerobic restoration between hard sessions. Can substitute for a rest day when the athlete needs movement without load. (Hörst regeneration climbing; Gresham active recovery)
cues: Grade 3+ below onsight — this should require virtually no effort
Focus on technique: silent feet, straight arms, deliberate hip positioning
If forearms are sore from previous days, stop at any onset of worsening
Conversational pace: ideal session to climb and talk with a partner simultaneously
~10 min per lap. 2 min rest between laps. Total 4 laps = ~50 min gentle movement

exercises.name: ARC Easy Traverse (Continuous)

prescription_defaults.notes: Easy traverses, 15-20 min continuous. Zero pump. Focus fluid movement.

exercises.description: ARC traversing: continuous horizontal movement at very easy grade. Traverses reduce the gravitational component of climbing and allow very long uninterrupted efforts without height anxiety. Ideal for early ARC blocks when 20-min continuous vertical feels psychologically demanding, or when the gym is busy. Same physiological target as arc_training with different movement pattern. (Gresham training bible; Neil Gresham low-intensity endurance guide)
cues: Traverse left-right-left continuously for the full 15-20 min without stepping off
Use any holds — grade is irrelevant on traverses, effort level is what matters
Zero pump is the goal — if forearms start to build, slow down or switch to larger holds
Mix movement patterns: cross-through, step-through, flagging. Use traverse as technique time
Hands near heart level on vertical sections — on slab traverses this is automatic

exercises.name: Weighted Pull-up

prescription_defaults.notes: Added weight via belt or vest. Progress load, not reps.

exercises.description: Pull-up with added load (weight belt, vest, or harness) for hypergravity training. Prerequisite: 15+ strict bodyweight pull-ups. Triggers neuromuscular adaptation to higher apparent bodyweight — on removal, bodyweight feels dramatically lighter. (Hörst 5x5 hypergravity protocol)
cues: Add 10-20% bodyweight to start — go up in small increments
Do NOT hang passive in dead hang between reps
Full range: dead hang to chin over bar
4-6 reps per set at 9/10 RPE
Reduce weight or stop if shoulder/elbow pain

exercises.name: L-Sit Pull-up

prescription_defaults.notes: Maintain L-sit throughout. If core fails first, reduce reps.

exercises.description: Pull-up with legs held at 90° (L-sit position). Combines vertical pulling with anterior core isometric demand. Significantly harder than standard pull-up due to lever arm — develops integrated pulling + core tension. (Hörst advanced pull variation)
cues: Achieve L-sit BEFORE initiating pull — not mid-movement
Legs perfectly horizontal, knees and feet together
Pull with same mechanics as standard pull-up
Core braced throughout — back must not arch
Assisted L-sit (band under feet) acceptable for progression

exercises.name: Archer Pull-up

prescription_defaults.notes: Asymmetric pullup. Alternate sides. One arm pulls, other assists on bar.

exercises.description: Unilateral pull-up variation with one arm extended straight to the side while the other pulls. Bridges gap between two-arm pull-ups and one-arm pull-up. Directly develops lock-off strength and unilateral lat engagement. (Hörst uneven-grip pull-ups, Hooper's Beta OAP progressions)
cues: Wide grip: working arm pulls, straight arm extends laterally
Straight arm PUSHES DOWN as working arm pulls up
Pull until chin is over working hand
Controlled slow lowering — 3s eccentric minimum
Alternate sides, both arms equal volume

exercises.name: Lock-off Isometric (Multi-Angle)

prescription_defaults.notes: Hold 5-10s at each angle. 90°, 120°, full lock. 3-5 sets per angle.

exercises.description: Isometric hold at multiple pull-up angles (90° and 120°). Trains the specific static strength needed for clipping, resting on routes, and dynamic move setup. Lattice: avoid deep lock-off (>120°) to protect elbows. (Hörst Frenchies protocol base, Lattice lock-off sessions)
cues: Hold at 90°: forearms horizontal — primary position
Hold at 120°: arms more open — secondary position
Never lock off fully closed (bicep on forearm)
Keep shoulders active and depressed throughout
Time under tension: 5-10s per hold, progress duration

exercises.name: One-Arm Pull-up (Assisted)

prescription_defaults.notes: Band or pulley assistance. Advanced. Focus controlled full ROM.

exercises.description: Assisted one-arm pull-up using towel, band, or pulley system. Primary progression toward one-arm pull-up. Develops unilateral lat and biceps strength. (Hörst uneven-grip protocol, Hooper's Beta 16-level OAP progression)
cues: Use minimum assistance needed to complete the rep with control
2-arm up, shift weight to working arm, 1-arm eccentric down (5s)
The eccentric is the key training stimulus — slow is mandatory
Gradually reduce assistance over weeks
Stop if elbow snaps or sharp pain — reduce load

exercises.name: Barbell Row

prescription_defaults.notes: Barbell or dumbbell row. Controlled eccentric.

exercises.description: Bent-over barbell or dumbbell horizontal row. Targets rhomboids, mid-trapezius, rear deltoid, and biceps. Heaviest loadable horizontal pull movement — effective for climbers who need significant upper-back volume to counterbalance anterior shoulder loading. Dumbbell variation is accessible and allows unilateral work.
cues: Hip hinge to ~45°: flat back, core braced, chest up
Pull bar to lower abdomen / upper hip — not chest
Lead with elbows driving back and up — do not shrug
Retract scapulae at the top: feel mid-back squeeze
3-second controlled eccentric lower — no bouncing off legs
If lower back fatigues before upper back, reduce load or switch to dumbbell single-arm row

exercises.name: Typewriter Pull-up

prescription_defaults.notes: Pull to top, traverse laterally at top position. Alternate direction.

exercises.description: Lateral pull-up traversing from one hand to the other at top position. Trains unilateral pulling and lateral shoulder stability. Directly mimics traversing moves on the wall. (Hooper's Beta, TrainingBeta — advanced pull variation)
cues: Wide grip, pull to top position with both arms
Slide laterally toward one hand until chin over wrist
Slide back through center to the other hand
Keep the non-pulling arm straight but active throughout
Slow and controlled — no swinging or momentum

exercises.name: Ring Push-up

prescription_defaults.notes: Instability from rings increases demand. Turn rings out at top.

exercises.description: Push-up performed on gymnastics rings. Increased difficulty vs floor pushup: instability activates rotator cuff and serratus anterior more intensely. Rings allow natural wrist rotation through the press, reducing wrist and shoulder stress. Excellent climbing-specific antagonist work.
cues: Rings at ~30 cm from floor — adjust height to control difficulty
Grip rings with knuckles facing out at the bottom of the movement
Allow rings to rotate inward (pronation) as you press up — natural movement
Body remains a rigid plank throughout: core and glutes engaged
To regress: raise rings higher (less bodyweight). To progress: elevate feet
Pause 2 seconds at top in full support position for shoulder stability benefit

exercises.name: Face Pull (Band)

prescription_defaults.notes: Also excellent as prehab. 3-4 sets, 15-20 reps.

exercises.description: Band or cable face pull targeting rear deltoid, rhomboids, and external rotators. Directly counteracts the forward-shoulder posture and internal rotation dominance caused by climbing. (Hörst rotator cuff protocol, Hooper's Beta)
cues: Anchor band at face or slightly above eye height
Pull to 90-90 position: elbows out, thumbs pointing up toward ceiling
Squeeze shoulder blades together at end range
Controlled return — resist the band on the way back
No shrugging the traps — keep shoulders away from ears

exercises.name: Front Lever (Tuck Progression)

prescription_defaults.notes: Advance to next progression when 4x15s is consistent. 3 min rest is minimum — this is near-maximal isometric effort.

exercises.description: Entry-level front lever progression. Knees tucked to chest reduces lever arm, making the horizontal hold achievable. Trains lat-core integration fundamental for body tension on overhangs. Progress to advanced tuck when 4 sets of 15s is consistently achievable. (climbing.com; heavyweightcali.com; Horst)
cues: Arms fully locked out — any elbow bend collapses the position
Hips level with shoulders — sagging hips reduce the training stimulus
Shoulders actively engaged: depressed and retracted (no shrugging)
Hollow body throughout: squeeze glutes and brace deep abs
Stop 1-2s before complete failure on each set — distribute effort across all sets

exercises.name: Hanging Leg Raise

prescription_defaults.notes: Straight legs to bar. Control the negative. No kipping.

exercises.description: Dynamic hip flexion from a dead hang strengthening hip flexors, lower abs and grip in a climbing-specific position. Directly trains the compression needed for toe hooks, bat hangs and high-steps on vertical and overhang. (Horst; UKC core guide)
cues: Start from a dead hang with shoulders actively engaged — not passive
Initiate with scapular depression before hip flexion, no kipping
Aim for legs parallel to floor or higher — not just a partial lift
Slow controlled eccentric: 2-3 seconds down, avoid swinging
Progression: bent-knee raises → straight-leg parallel → toes to bar

exercises.name: Ab Wheel Rollout

prescription_defaults.notes: Ab wheel recommended; towel on smooth floor works too.

exercises.description: High-demand anti-extension movement requiring full-body tension from fingers to feet. Trains the ability to resist spine extension under load — directly transfers to body tension on steep overhangs and roof climbing. (Horst; UKC core training)
cues: Start kneeling — progress to standing only when kneeling form is perfect
Keep arms straight throughout — do not bend elbows
Neutral lower back at all times: no sagging or hyperextension
Roll only as far as position can be maintained — partial range at first is fine
Exhale on the roll-out (braces core), inhale on return

exercises.name: Pallof Press (Anti-Rotation)

prescription_defaults.notes: Press and hold. Resist rotation. Alternate sides.

exercises.description: Anti-rotation press training obliques and deep stabilizers to resist rotational forces. Directly transfers to twisting moves, hip flags and barn-door prevention. Requires band or cable. (UKC core guide; Horst conditioning principles)
cues: Band or cable anchored at chest height to the side
Press straight out slowly — feel the oblique tension resist rotation
Zero rotation in pelvis and torso throughout the press
Pause at full extension for 1-2s before returning
Train both directions each set — do not skip the weaker side

exercises.name: Side Plank

prescription_defaults.notes: Each side. Stack feet or stagger. Hips high.

exercises.description: Lateral anti-rotation isometric targeting obliques, lateral hip stabilizers and hip abductors. Essential for flagging, hip drops and side-pull sequences where the body is under rotational stress. (inSPIRE Rock; Horst core series)
cues: Ear, shoulder, hip and ankle in one straight line — no hip sag
Hips stacked vertically — do not let top hip roll forward
Breathe steadily and maintain full tension throughout
Regression: bottom knee bent to shorten the lever
Progression: top arm overhead, or top foot raised

exercises.name: Dead Bug

prescription_defaults.notes: Slow and controlled. Press low back into floor. Breathe out on extension.

exercises.description: Anti-extension dynamic stability drill training contralateral coordination and deep core activation. Strengthens the stabilizers that control limb movements independently while keeping the spine neutral — transfers to moving feet precisely on steep terrain. (UKC core guide; inSPIRE Rock)
cues: Lower back pressed firmly into the floor for every single rep — non-negotiable
Extend opposite arm and leg simultaneously in a slow controlled arc
Exhale fully on the extension to brace deep core
Never sacrifice back position for range of motion — reduce range if needed
Progress: add light dumbbell in hand or resistance band on foot

exercises.name: Windshield Wipers (Hanging)

prescription_defaults.notes: Controlled rotation. Legs to bar, rotate side to side.

exercises.description: Advanced rotational core exercise. From a dead hang, legs rotate side to side demanding high body tension, rotational control and grip endurance. Do not attempt before achieving 10+ clean toes-to-bar. (Horst; alpinetrek.co.uk core guide)
cues: Keep legs straight and pressed together throughout the rotation
Control the arc — avoid using momentum to swing the legs
Pause briefly at each side before reversing direction
Shoulders actively engaged throughout — not passive hanging
Reduce range to 45° if form breaks at full rotation

exercises.name: Toes to Bar

prescription_defaults.notes: Strict form. No kipping. Full compression at top.

exercises.description: Classic hanging hip flexion/compression combining grip, shoulder stability and full core engagement. Trains the same compression chain used in bat hangs and toe hooks, in a fully hanging position. Prerequisite for windshield_wipers. (UKC core guide; inSPIRE Rock)
cues: Begin with a hollow body position in the dead hang before initiating
Initiate with scapular depression first, then drive hips up
Touch the bar with feet — do not stop short
Slow controlled eccentric on the way down: 2-3 seconds
If too hard: progress from hanging knee raises → straight-leg raises → toes to bar

exercises.name: Wrist Curl (Flexion)

prescription_defaults.notes: Light dumbbell. Slow and controlled. Forearm on knee.

exercises.description: Dumbbell wrist curl strengthening flexor carpi radialis and ulnaris. Complements extensor work for balanced wrist stability and medial epicondylitis prevention. (Hörst wrist stabilizer protocol)
cues: Forearm flat on bench, wrist hanging off edge palm-up
Full range: from full extension down to full flexion
Slow eccentric lowering phase 2-3 seconds
Light weight — this is preventive work, not strength
Keep fingers relaxed throughout

exercises.name: Reverse Wrist Curl (Extension)

prescription_defaults.notes: Light dumbbell. Slow and controlled. Forearm on knee, palm down.

exercises.description: Dumbbell reverse wrist curl targeting extensor carpi radialis longus/brevis and ulnaris. The single most underutilized muscle group in climbing training. Essential for lateral epicondylitis prevention. (Hörst: 'paramount to train wrist in extended position')
cues: Forearm in pronation on bench, wrist hanging off edge
Lead with knuckles upward into extension
Slow eccentric: 3-4 seconds on the lowering phase
Do NOT curl fingers to compensate — isolate the wrist
Keep load light enough to maintain perfect form for all reps

exercises.name: Forearm Pronation/Supination

prescription_defaults.notes: Hammer or light dumbbell. Slow and controlled.

exercises.description: Controlled dumbbell or stick pronation and supination for medial elbow health and rotational forearm strength. Addresses the rotational demands of dynamic climbing moves. Core of Hörst's climber's elbow protocol.
cues: Elbow at 90°, upper arm against body or rested on thigh
Slow rotation in both directions — full range each way
Control the eccentric in both directions equally
Weight should feel light — this is endurance and tendon health
No sharp pain — reduce weight or range if needed

exercises.name: Finger Extensor Training (Rubber Band)

prescription_defaults.notes: Rubber band around fingers. 3-4 sets, 15-20 reps. Daily if desired.

exercises.description: Rubber band or Powerfingers finger extension to balance flexor dominance. Warmup standard and injury prevention baseline for all climbers. Hörst: 'sufficient for warm-up and beginners, but not a substitute for full extensor strength work'.
cues: Spread all fingers fully against resistance from closed fist
Full range — completely open from fully closed
Light enough to feel activation, not fatigue
15-25 reps as warmup; add sets and resistance for strength phase
Combine with wrist extension work (reverse curl) for full extensor training

exercises.name: Elbow Eccentric Curl (Tyler Twist)

prescription_defaults.notes: Slow eccentric. Key exercise for elbow tendinopathy prevention. Tyler twist / reverse Tyler twist.

exercises.description: Eccentric biceps curl targeting the distal biceps tendon and brachialis to address medial epicondylitis and golfer's elbow. The slow lowering phase is the primary therapeutic stimulus. (Dave Macleod 10-ways elbow protocol, StrengthClimbing elbow guide)
cues: Use other hand to assist the concentric (lifting) phase
All effort on slow 4-6 second eccentric lowering
Keep upper arm vertical and still throughout
Mild discomfort during eccentric is normal and expected
Sharp pain = stop immediately

exercises.name: Shoulder CARs (Controlled Articular Rotation)

prescription_defaults.notes: Full range. Slow and controlled. 3 reps each direction per arm.

exercises.description: Controlled Articular Rotation (CAR) for the shoulder joint. Maintains end-range mobility, stimulates joint mechanoreceptors, and serves as active daily self-assessment. Gold standard FRC/Kinstretch joint health practice. (Prehab Guys, Rehab Hero, Joe Gambino DPT)
cues: Brace core and glutes fully before moving the arm
Move through the LARGEST circle you can control
Isolate to the shoulder — no spinal twist or elbow bend
Slow and deliberate: aim for 10+ seconds per full rotation
Note any pinching or restriction — these are signals, not to push through

exercises.name: Silent Feet Drill

prescription_defaults.notes: Climb well below onsight. Focus: zero noise on footplacements.

exercises.description: Footwork precision drill: place every foot silently with zero audible contact. Forces conscious attention to exact toe placement, hold orientation and weight transfer. Directly reduces sloppy footwork which bleeds energy and limits technique on any terrain. (Jorgeson/Wallach via climbing.com; Paige Claassen footwork series)
cues: Eyes on the foothold until the foot is weighted — never look away early
Place the toe first, then slowly transfer weight — never slam or drop
If any sound is heard, downclimb the move and repeat it silently
Grade 2 below onsight — this is not a fitness drill, it is a precision drill
Practice every warm-up set: silent feet is a lifetime habit, not a beginner exercise

exercises.name: No Readjust Drill

prescription_defaults.notes: Place foot once, no adjustment. Forces precision. Well below onsight grade.

exercises.description: Footwork commitment drill: place the foot once and do not adjust it. Trains first-placement accuracy and the confidence to weight an imperfectly placed foot rather than waste time and energy readjusting. Inspired by Margo Hayes and Janja Garnbret's footwork economy. (Paige Claassen; climbing.com)
cues: Look at the foothold before moving the foot — plan the exact placement point
Place and commit: no micro-adjustments, no scoping, no second placement
If the foot slips, note why and retry that specific move — learn the error
Grade 2 below onsight so upper body is not a limiting factor
Progress: move closer to onsight grade while maintaining zero readjusts

exercises.name: Downclimbing Drill

prescription_defaults.notes: Climb up, climb down controlled. Every route/boulder. Builds eccentric strength and awareness.

exercises.description: Downclimb every route or problem after topping out. Builds footwork precision and body awareness in the direction most climbers neglect — feet-first, legs doing the work. Dramatically improves reading ability and foot confidence on first attempts. (Gripped; 99boulders footwork drills)
cues: Feet lead down — use legs to lower bodyweight, not arms
Look down at each foothold before weighting it: the same skill as upclimbing
Keep arms straight and relaxed — downclimbing should not pump your forearms
Grade 1-2 below onsight so movement quality can be maintained throughout
Downclimb all warm-up sets — make it a session default, not an occasional drill

exercises.name: Slow Climbing (Count to 3)

prescription_defaults.notes: Count to 3 between every move. Forces reading, breathing, and deliberate movement.

exercises.description: Climb at half normal speed or slower, pausing on every hold. Exposes inefficiencies in balance, hip positioning and weight distribution that normal-pace climbing masks. Fundamental drill for developing deliberate movement and reading body position. (Hooper's Beta technique series; trainingforclimbing.com)
cues: Every move takes at least 3 seconds — use a count if needed
Pause in each position: feel where the weight is, check hip position
Arms straight and relaxed between moves — slow climbing reveals grip dependency
Breathe on every move — slow climbing is the ideal drill for breathing awareness too
Grade 3 below onsight: technique focus demands very familiar terrain

exercises.name: Flag Practice (Inside/Outside/Drop Knee)

prescription_defaults.notes: Inside flag, outside flag, drop knee practice. Easy boulders. Focus body tension and balance.

exercises.description: Dedicated flag and hip positioning drill: on each move, consciously choose and execute a flag (inside, outside, or back-flag) to prevent barn-door and maintain hip proximity to wall. Builds the automatic body tension and hip awareness required on overhanging terrain. (Hooper's Beta flagging guide; trainingforclimbing.com hip technique)
cues: Identify the barn-door risk before making each move — plan the flag
Inside flag: foot crosses body to opposite side, pushes into wall
Outside flag: foot extends behind and out on same side as moving hand
Back-flag: rear leg extends back and down to counter rotation
Grade 2 below onsight: technique must be exaggerated and deliberate, not reactive

exercises.name: Breathing Awareness

prescription_defaults.notes: Climb easy problems focusing only on breath rhythm. Inhale on setup, exhale on hard moves. Notice when you hold your breath and correct.

exercises.description: Conscious breathing drill during easy climbing to build automatic breath-movement coordination. Reduces oxygen debt and tension on harder routes by training diaphragmatic breathing under low-intensity climbing load (Husbands-Bosworth relaxation principle).
cues: Climb 2-3 grades below max on easy terrain
Inhale through nose during setup moves, exhale through mouth on effort
Pause at each rest position and take 2-3 deep belly breaths
Notice any breath-holding and consciously release
Shake out arms while breathing deeply at every good hold

exercises.name: Foothold Stare Drill

prescription_defaults.notes: Watch your foot contact the hold and stay watching until fully weighted. Do not look away until weight is committed.

exercises.description: Visual tracking drill to eliminate sloppy foot placements. Force yourself to watch each foot all the way onto the hold and not look away until fully weighted. Builds the neural pathway for precise, confident footwork (Hörst precision footwork method).
cues: Eyes track foot from selection to placement to weighting
Do not look away until full weight is on the foot
Place toe precisely on the best part of the hold
Climb 2-3 grades below max to maintain focus
Zero readjustments allowed after initial placement

exercises.name: Hip Rotation Drill

prescription_defaults.notes: On every move, consciously rotate hips toward the wall. Turn hip of reaching hand into the wall before initiating the reach.

exercises.description: Deliberate hip turn-in drill to build automatic hip rotation on steep terrain. Rotating the hip into the wall shifts centre of gravity closer to feet, reduces arm load, and extends reach (Hörst twist-lock / hip-turn principle).
cues: Before each reach, rotate the same-side hip toward the wall
Lead with the hip, not the hand
Feel weight shift onto the outside edge of the opposite foot
Exaggerate the rotation on easy terrain to build the pattern
Combine with drop-knee on steep sections

exercises.name: Hover Hands

prescription_defaults.notes: Hover hand 2-3cm above next hold for a full second before grabbing. Forces deliberate movement and eliminates lunging.

exercises.description: Movement quality drill where each hand must hover above the target hold for one full second before grabbing it. Eliminates grabby, rushed movement and builds controlled, deliberate reaching (Husbands-Bosworth precision reaching method).
cues: Reach to the hold but stop 2-3cm short and hover
Hold the hover position for a full second
Only then close the hand and grip the hold
Maintain stable body position during the hover
If you lunge or grab immediately, repeat the move

exercises.name: One Hand Climbing

prescription_defaults.notes: Climb easy problems using only one hand. Alternate left and right each rep. Forces extreme reliance on footwork, balance, and body positioning.

exercises.description: Constraint drill where one hand is kept behind the back while climbing easy terrain. Massively amplifies dependence on footwork, hip position, and balance. Builds body awareness and foot trust by removing the compensation of the second hand (differential learning method).
cues: Keep one hand behind your back or in a chalk bag
Climb very easy problems (4+ grades below max)
Place feet with extreme precision — they are your lifeline
Use hip shifts and body tension to stay in balance
Alternate lead hand each problem

exercises.name: Sloth / Monkey Move

prescription_defaults.notes: Alternate between ultra-slow (sloth) and fast-dynamic (monkey) on the same easy problem. Builds tempo awareness and movement versatility.

exercises.description: Tempo contrast drill alternating between extremely slow, controlled climbing (sloth) and fast, dynamic movement (monkey) on the same easy problem. Develops movement versatility, tempo awareness, and the ability to shift gears between static and dynamic styles (differential learning method).
cues: Sloth mode: move as slowly as physically possible, minimum 5s per move
Monkey mode: climb fluidly and quickly with minimal pauses
Same problem, back to back — sloth then monkey
Maintain perfect technique in both modes
Notice which mode feels harder and train that more

exercises.name: Sticky Feet Drill

prescription_defaults.notes: Place feet with zero noise. If you hear your shoe touch the hold, repeat the placement. Train precise, deliberate foot contact.

exercises.description: Precision footwork drill where every foot placement must be completely silent. Any audible contact with the hold means the placement was imprecise and must be repeated. Builds proprioceptive awareness and eliminates sloppy, stamped placements (Hörst quiet-feet principle).
cues: Place each foot with zero audible contact on the hold
If you hear any noise, pull the foot back and re-place
Watch your foot all the way onto the hold
Climb 2-3 grades below max to maintain focus
Focus on toe tip precision, not full-foot smearing

exercises.name: Straight Arms Drill

prescription_defaults.notes: Climb with arms as straight as possible at all times. Only bend to pull through the move, then immediately straighten. Builds skeletal hanging habit.

exercises.description: Body position drill forcing straight-arm climbing to build the habit of hanging on skeleton rather than muscles. Keeping arms extended reduces bicep fatigue and shifts load to the stronger skeletal system (Hörst straight-arm climbing principle).
cues: Keep arms fully extended whenever not actively moving
Only bend arms to execute a move, then straighten immediately
Sink hips low and away from the wall on vertical terrain
Use hip turns and high steps to keep arms long on steep terrain
If you notice bent arms at rest, shake out and reset

exercises.name: Tap and Place

prescription_defaults.notes: Tap the target foothold gently with your toe, lift away, then place precisely. The tap forces you to rehearse the placement before committing.

exercises.description: Footwork precision drill where you tap each foothold lightly with your toe before placing your foot on it. The tap rehearsal prevents rushed placements and trains the foot-eye coordination pathway for accurate first-attempt contact (Climbing Research precision footwork protocol).
cues: Lightly tap the foothold with your toe tip first
Lift your foot back off after the tap
Now place with full precision and weight the foot
Zero readjustments after the final placement
Maintain focus even when pumped or tired

exercises.name: Three Limb Drill

prescription_defaults.notes: Climb using only 3 contact points at any time. Before grabbing a new hold, release one limb. Forces deliberate sequencing and balance awareness.

exercises.description: Constraint drill where only three limbs may contact the wall at any time. Before establishing a new contact, one limb must be released first. Builds deliberate move sequencing, balance awareness, and body tension under reduced support (differential learning constraint method).
cues: Maximum 3 points of contact at any time
Plan each move: decide which limb to release before reaching
Maintain body tension through the transition
Use flagging and hip shifts to stay balanced on 3 points
Climb easy problems — focus on control, not difficulty

exercises.name: Hip Opener Flow (Frog/Pigeon/90-90)

prescription_defaults.notes: Hold each position 45-60s. Breathe deeply. Post-session or rest day.

exercises.description: Continuous hip mobility flow sequencing through external rotation positions — 90/90, pigeon, frog, butterfly, and deep squat. Targets hip flexors, external rotators, adductors, and glutes. Directly improves high-step reach, flag position range, and knee-to-wall engagement on steep terrain. 10-minute continuous flow format.
cues: Move slowly and continuously — this is a flow, not held stretches
Breathe into each position: inhale 4 counts, exhale 4 counts
90/90: both shins at 90°, sit tall, slight lean forward over front shin
Pigeon: front shin parallel to top of mat, square hips to the floor
Deep squat: heels flat if possible, chest up, elbows pressing knees open
Never force rotation — explore the end of easy range, then breathe

exercises.name: Shoulder Stretch Flow (Pec/Cross-body/Sleeper)

prescription_defaults.notes: Pec stretch, cross-body, sleeper stretch. Hold 45-60s each.

exercises.description: Upper body flexibility sequence targeting posterior shoulder capsule, pectorals, biceps, and overhead range. Includes cross-body shoulder, chest doorframe stretch, overhead tricep/lat pull, and thread-the-needle. Addresses the anterior chest tightness and limited overhead range common in regular climbers.
cues: Cross-body shoulder: pull arm across chest at shoulder height, relax the stretched shoulder down
Doorframe chest: forearms on doorframe at 90°, step through slowly — stop if sharp pain
Thread-the-needle: from all-fours, slide one arm under body until shoulder touches floor
Overhead lat: one arm overhead, other hand gentle pull at wrist — feel stretch down side of torso
Hold each position 30s minimum — do not rush
After hard climbing session: focus extra time on posterior shoulder and pec minor

exercises.name: Forearm Stretches (Wrist Extension/Flexion)

prescription_defaults.notes: Essential after every climbing session. 2-3 min minimum. Wrist extension and flexion on floor.

exercises.description: Forearm flexor and extensor stretching sequence essential for finger and wrist health in climbers. Targets the forearm flexor group (fingers/wrist), wrist extensors, and finger flexors individually. Hörst and Eva López both explicitly prescribe post-session forearm stretching as injury prevention. 2 minutes minimum post-climbing.
cues: Flexor stretch: arm straight in front, palm up, other hand gently pulls fingers toward floor. Feel stretch in underside of forearm.
Extensor stretch: arm straight in front, palm down, other hand gently pushes fingers toward floor.
Hold each stretch 30s minimum per arm
Never bounce or force — tendons and pulleys stretch very slowly
Intensity: mild pull only. Zero pain. Any sharp pain → stop.
Perform after every climbing session while forearms are still warm

exercises.name: Full Body Stretch Flow (Yin-inspired)

prescription_defaults.notes: Yin-yoga inspired. Hips, shoulders, spine, hamstrings. Hold 60s+ per position.

exercises.description: Complete 15-minute post-session flexibility routine covering all major muscle groups used in climbing: forearms, shoulders, lats, hip flexors, hamstrings, hip external rotators, and quads. Intended as end-of-session cooldown. Low intensity, passive holds, systematic top-to-bottom or bottom-to-top sequencing.
cues: Sequence suggestion: forearms → shoulders → lats → hip flexors → hamstrings → hips → quads
Minimum 30s per position — use a timer
Aim for zero tension by the end of each hold before moving on
This is the session's reward: allow the nervous system to downregulate
Add breathing practice: 4-7-8 pattern (inhale 4, hold 7, exhale 8) during long holds

exercises.name: Active Hip Mobility (CARs/High Step/Frog)

prescription_defaults.notes: High step drill, hip CARs, active frog. Dynamic, controlled movement.

exercises.description: Dynamic hip mobility drills performed through active range of motion — hip CARs (controlled articular rotations), leg swings, and active 90/90 switches. Unlike passive stretching, active work builds strength through the newly acquired range. Directly improves high-step control, drop-knee engagement, and flag stability.
cues: Hip CARs: standing, slowly draw the largest circle possible with your knee — own that range
Leg swings: 10 forward/back and 10 lateral per leg — controlled pendulum, not momentum
90/90 active switches: sit in 90/90 and actively lift each knee, no hands for assistance
Slower is harder and more effective — do not rush through the motion
If hips pop or click without pain: normal. If click with pain: reduce range

exercises.name: Wall Handstand Hold (Belly-to-Wall)

prescription_defaults.notes: Belly-to-wall. Arms straight, shoulders elevated. 3-4 x 20-30s.

exercises.description: Chest-to-wall handstand hold — hands 15-20 cm from wall, belly facing wall, walk feet up and establish vertical alignment. Foundational static handstand skill. Develops shoulder overhead stability, wrist strength, and body tension. Prerequisite for all other handstand work.
cues: Face wall, hands 15-20 cm from baseboard — palms flat, fingers spread
Walk feet up the wall and step hands closer until body is vertical
Active shoulders: push floor away aggressively — do not collapse into shoulders
Squeeze glutes and engage core to prevent lower back arch
Eyes look at the floor between hands — do not look at the wall
20s hold is the entry target — build to 60s before progressing

exercises.name: Wall Walk-up

prescription_defaults.notes: Walk up from pushup position to handstand at wall. Controlled descent.

exercises.description: Walking feet up the wall from push-up position to fully vertical handstand, then walking back down. Trains the handstand entry, overhead shoulder stability, and proprioception under load. A safer and more controllable handstand entry than kicking up from the floor. Also a useful shoulder strength exercise in its own right.
cues: Start in push-up position feet close to wall
Walk feet up the wall and hands progressively closer to wall simultaneously
Aim to reach vertical with hands close to wall (10-15 cm)
Pause at the top for 2-3 seconds before walking back down with control
Speed is the enemy: slow, controlled movements improve stability and strength
2 reps = 1 up and 1 down controlled

exercises.name: Handstand Shoulder Taps (Wall)

prescription_defaults.notes: In handstand at wall, tap opposite shoulder. Anti-rotation + stability.

exercises.description: In chest-to-wall handstand: briefly lift one hand and tap the opposite shoulder, then return and alternate. Unilateral loading of each shoulder in the overhead position. Develops the lateral stability and wrist control needed for freestanding balance. 4 reps = 2 per side.
cues: Only attempt once wall hold is stable for 20+ seconds
Shift weight entirely to one hand before lifting the other
Keep the tap quick: 1 second off the floor maximum
Core and glutes must remain tight — no hip sag during the tap
If hips rotate during taps, reduce rep count and focus on core tension first

exercises.name: Freestanding Handstand Practice

prescription_defaults.notes: Skill practice. Many short attempts, full rest. Quality over quantity.

exercises.description: 10-minute dedicated freestanding handstand practice session — kicking up, finding balance, and accumulating freestanding time. Long-term skill development, not a strength set. Balance work adapts slowly; consistent daily or every-other-day practice with low fatigue is superior to infrequent high-volume sessions.
cues: Kick-up: one foot steps close to hands, powerful swing of back leg overhead
Balanced position: slight hollow body (not arched), active shoulders, eyes on floor
Use a wall as spotter but attempt to find the balance point independently
Pirouetting out of failed attempts is safer than crashing — learn cartwheel bail
Track freestanding seconds per session — improvement is measured in seconds, not minutes

exercises.name: Handstand Push-up (Wall)

prescription_defaults.notes: Wall-supported HSPU. Full ROM. Head to floor. Control the negative.

exercises.description: Strict wall handstand push-up. From chest-to-wall handstand: lower crown of head toward floor, pause, press back to full lockout. Targets anterior deltoid, triceps, and upper trapezius under full bodyweight overhead load. Demanding exercise — requires solid 30s+ wall hold and consistent full-extension overhead pressing strength as prerequisite.
cues: Only attempt if freestanding handstand or 30s+ wall hold is established
Lower slowly: 3-second controlled eccentric to head barely touching floor
Press to complete lockout — no partial reps
If elbow flare occurs: keep elbows slightly inside the wrist line (not wide flare)
Stop at the first rep where lockout is incomplete — do not grind through form breakdown
Pike push-up is the direct regression if reps are not achievable

exercises.name: Jump Rope (Cardio Conditioning)

prescription_defaults.notes: Jump rope recommended but optional. Good pulse raiser alternative.

exercises.description: Jump rope (skipping) cardio conditioning — continuous or interval skipping for pulse raise and cardiovascular warm-up. One of the highest-efficiency low-skill cardio tools: requires minimal equipment, zero gym footprint, and raises heart rate rapidly. Standard tool in climbing gym warm-ups. NOTE: pattern field flagged as vocabulary gap ('carry' is incorrect — update vocab to 'locomotion' first).
cues: Basic bounce: both feet together, minimal wrist movement, rope turns from wrists not elbows
Aim for consistent 70-80 RPM rhythm — not maximum speed
Land on balls of feet, soft knees — never flat-footed
5 min continuous is the baseline. If tripping frequently, shorten to 2×2 min with 1 min rest
No jump rope? Simulate: same footwork and arm motion without rope — nearly equal HR benefit

exercises.name: Turkish Get-up

prescription_defaults.notes: Kettlebell or dumbbell. Alternate sides. Slow and controlled. Full body coordination.

exercises.description: Turkish get-up (TGU) — full floor-to-standing sequence while holding a weight overhead in one arm. Trains integrated shoulder stability, hip mobility, and core rotation through the largest range of motion of any single exercise. Bechtel and Hörst both recommend TGU for climbing-specific general athleticism and shoulder resilience. 2 reps per side = very high quality work volume.
cues: Start lying, arm vertical with weight directly above shoulder, eyes on the weight throughout
Sequence: roll to elbow → press to hand → bridge hips up → sweep back knee → kneeling → stand
Reverse the sequence to lower — every step is controlled
Weight is a kettlebell ideally, but a dumbbell or even a shoe works to learn
2 reps/side at quality > 5 reps/side rushed. Never sacrifice the eye-on-weight rule
Beginners: learn with no weight first, then a shoe, then a light kettlebell

exercises.name: Farmer's Carry

prescription_defaults.notes: Heavy dumbbells or kettlebells. Walk with control. Suitcase carry for anti-lateral flexion.

exercises.description: Farmer's carry — walking with heavy loads held at sides. Trains grip endurance, anti-lateral-flexion core stability, and loaded walking mechanics. Carries are recommended in Hörst and Bechtel programming as general conditioning that builds real-world climbing grip endurance and trunk stability without specific climbing movements.
cues: Weight in each hand — kettlebells, dumbbells, or loaded buckets all work
Stand tall: shoulders retracted and depressed, chest up, core braced
Steps should be controlled — not waddling or leaning to either side
30s carry at chosen weight, rest 60s, repeat 3 times
Load: should feel heavy in grip by 20s. If grip is not the limiter, weight is too light
Single-arm variation: one side at a time trains anti-lateral-flexion more specifically

exercises.name: Bear Crawl

prescription_defaults.notes: Quadrupedia. Shoulder stability + coordination. Knees off ground. Slow and controlled.

exercises.description: Bear crawl — quadruped locomotion with knees hovering 5 cm off floor. Trains anterior core stability, contralateral coordination, and shoulder stability through a full locomotion pattern. Used in Bechtel general conditioning circuits and Uphill Athlete climbing programs. NOTE: pattern field flagged as vocabulary gap ('carry' is incorrect — update vocab to 'locomotion' first).
cues: Start on all-fours, knees hovering 5 cm off floor — do not let knees touch
Move right hand and left foot simultaneously, then left hand and right foot
Hips stay level — avoid rocking side to side
Forward AND backward: bear crawl forward 10m, then back 10m = 1 set
Slow is harder and more useful: 2-second steps develop more stability than rushing
Harder variant: backwards bear crawl, or with weight vest

exercises.name: Band Pull-apart (Scapular Daily)

prescription_defaults.notes: Can do daily. 2-3 sets of 15-20. Essential for shoulder health.

exercises.description: Band pull-apart targeting posterior deltoid, rhomboids, and mid-trapezius. Reinforces scapular retraction and counteracts the chronic shoulder protraction pattern of climbing. Effective complement to face pulls. (Hooper's Beta, Physivantage)
cues: Arms straight at shoulder height, palms down or up
Pull band to chest — focus on squeezing shoulder blades together
Control the return — resist the band slowly
Light band: quality of scapular retraction over load
Keep elbows straight throughout the movement

exercises.name: Route Redpoint Attempt

prescription_defaults.notes: Project-level routes. Full rest between attempts. Focus on linking crux sequences.

exercises.description: Full redpoint attempts on project-level routes. High-intensity output with full rest between attempts. The primary training goal is project-specific skill acquisition: reading crux sequences, managing pump tactically, and ingraining beta under fatigue. Distinct from training exercises — this is performance-oriented climbing. Record every attempt: holds used, sections recovered, failure point. (Hörst redpoint taper protocol; standard competition prep)
cues: Full rest between attempts: minimum 5-10 min, up to 20 min for hard projects
Two quality attempts are worth more than four fatigued attempts — stop if form degrades
After a fall, immediately identify the failure: technique, fitness, or mental? Log it
Rehearse the crux section individually during rest if execution was messy
Plan attempts around peak freshness: first or second attempt of the session is usually best

exercises.name: Forearm & Wrist Stretch (Cooldown)

prescription_defaults.notes: Flexor and extensor stretches. Prayer and reverse prayer. Hold each side.

exercises.description: Brief post-session forearm and wrist stretch targeting finger flexors and wrist extensors. Essential cooldown element for finger health — consistently prescribed by Hörst, Eva López, and Lattice. Keeps connective tissue supple between sessions.
cues: Flexor: arm extended, palm up, opposite hand pulls fingers toward floor — underside forearm stretch
Extensor: arm extended, palm down, opposite hand pushes hand toward floor — top of forearm stretch
Hold each 30s minimum per arm (not 20s — that's too short)
Both arms, both directions: 4 stretches total, ~2 min
Intensity: 4/10 pull — never force. Tendons respond to gentle sustained load only

exercises.name: Pigeon Stretch (Cooldown)

prescription_defaults.notes: Each side. Keep hips square. Breathe into the stretch.

exercises.description: Pigeon pose hip external rotator stretch targeting piriformis, glute medius, and deep hip external rotators. One of the most effective single-side hip stretches available. Regular practice improves drop-knee range and high-step reach. Hold each side minimum 60s (30s yields minimal connective tissue benefit).
cues: Front shin parallel to the top edge of mat — more parallel = deeper stretch
Square hips toward floor — do not allow the hip to collapse to one side
Walk hands forward and lower torso for deeper stretch once hips settle
30s is the minimum, 60-90s per side is the goal for meaningful adaptation
Avoid if sharp knee pain — try a supine figure-4 stretch instead

exercises.name: Frog Stretch (Cooldown)

prescription_defaults.notes: Knees wide, hips sink toward floor. Gentle hold, no bouncing.

exercises.description: Frog stretch targeting hip adductors, groin, and hip external rotators from a wide kneeling position. Excellent complement to pigeon — reaches the adductors which pigeon misses. Particularly useful for climbers who struggle with heels-in high steps and wide stemming positions.
cues: From all-fours: walk knees wide until a gentle pull is felt in the inner thighs
Feet directly behind knees, feet flat (heels out, toes in) or neutral
Hips sink slowly toward floor — do not force
Hands walk forward to increase stretch intensity
Hold 60s — 30s is insufficient for meaningful adductor adaptation
Breathe into the tension: exhale and allow further release

exercises.name: Shoulder & Chest Stretch (Cooldown)

prescription_defaults.notes: Doorway stretch or wall pec stretch. Each side. Open chest and anterior shoulder.

exercises.description: Chest and shoulder stretch targeting anterior deltoid, pectorals, and shoulder internal rotators — the muscles most shortened by climbing's dominant pulling pattern. Cross-body arm stretch or doorframe chest stretch. Compensates for anterior chest dominance and helps maintain healthy shoulder posture.
cues: Option A: arm across chest — pull at elbow, relax the shoulder being stretched downward
Option B: hand on doorframe at shoulder height — gently rotate away from the frame
Hold 30s minimum per arm/side
Avoid shrugging the shoulder being stretched — it must stay depressed and relaxed
Breathe slowly throughout — the stretch deepens naturally with each exhale

exercises.name: Standing Forward Fold (Cooldown)

prescription_defaults.notes: Soft knees. Hang heavy. Breathe and relax into the stretch.

exercises.description: Seated hamstring stretch — forward fold or single-leg extension targeting biceps femoris, semimembranosus, and semitendinosus. Hamstring flexibility directly supports high heel placements and seated rest positions on overhangs. Seated forward fold or supine single-leg hamstring stretch.
cues: Seated: legs straight, flex feet, hinge from hips (not waist) — keep spine long
Do NOT round the lower back — prioritise a flat back over reaching further
Supine option: lying flat, loop a strap over foot, pull leg toward ceiling — safer for lower back
Hold 30-60s per side
