Reaching further is less important than keeping the pelvis in anterior tilt (long spine)

exercises.name: Supine Spinal Twist (Cooldown)

prescription_defaults.notes: Each side. Knees stacked, arms wide. Let gravity do the work.

exercises.description: Supine spinal twist targeting thoracic rotation, glute medius, and IT band. Decompresses the spine after climbing sessions, restores rotational range, and counteracts the sustained thoracic flexion of climbing posture. Performed lying on back, one knee across body.
cues: Lie on back, bend one knee to 90°, drop it across the body to the floor
Opposite arm extends along floor at shoulder height — shoulder stays flat on floor
Turn gaze away from the knee for full spinal rotation
Hold 30-60s per side — let gravity do the work, no forcing
Exhale to allow deeper rotation — do not force with hands

exercises.name: Deep Squat Hold (Cooldown)

prescription_defaults.notes: Heels down. Hold a support if needed. Open hips and thoracic spine.

exercises.description: Deep bodyweight squat hold targeting ankle dorsiflexion, hip external rotation, and adductors simultaneously. One position that trains three common climbing flexibility demands at once. Useful pre- and post-session. Regular practice improves heels-flat squat depth which transfers to low-foot placements and rest positions.
cues: Feet slightly wider than hips, toes angled out ~30°
Heels flat if possible — if not, elevate heels on a small block initially
Elbows press inside of knees to encourage hip external rotation
Chest up, spine neutral — do not let the lower back round excessively
Hold 30-60s. If it feels easy, walk feet slightly closer together

exercises.name: Cossack Squat (Active Flexibility)

prescription_defaults.notes: Alternating sides. Full depth. Heel stays down on working leg.

exercises.description: Cossack squat — deep lateral lunge to each side, with one leg fully extended and the other deeply bent. Challenges adductors, lateral hamstring, and ankle dorsiflexion simultaneously in an active end-range position. Higher transfer to climbing than passive stretches — combines flexibility with strength through range.
cues: From wide stance: shift weight laterally over one foot, bending that knee deeply
Extended leg: foot flexed with toes pointing up, or heel on floor — both valid
Torso stays upright — resist the urge to lean excessively forward
Move slowly: 3-second controlled lower, pause at bottom, 3-second return
If ankle rolls or heel lifts on bent leg, use a small plate under the heel

exercises.name: Active Straight Leg Raise

prescription_defaults.notes: Supine. Use hip flexors to raise straight leg. Hold 2s at top. Each side.

exercises.description: Standing active straight-leg raise — lift one leg forward as high as possible using hip flexors and quad only, without assistance. Tests and trains active hamstring flexibility and hip flexor strength simultaneously. More functionally relevant than passive hamstring stretching for high-foot placements.
cues: Standing, hold a wall for balance
Swing leg forward as high as possible under muscular control — no momentum kick
Maintaining a neutral spine — do not posteriorly tilt the pelvis to gain height
Hold peak position 2s before lowering with control
8 reps/side: quality over height. Better to stop at 70° with perfect form than 90° with compensation

exercises.name: 90/90 Hip Switch (Active Flexibility)

prescription_defaults.notes: Seated. Knees at 90 degrees. Rotate from one side to the other with control.

exercises.description: 90/90 hip external and internal rotation stretch — both hip joints at 90° angles in a seated position, one in external rotation (front shin), one in internal rotation (back shin). Directly trains and assesses hip rotational range. Highly recommended across Lattice and Bechtel protocols for identifying hip asymmetries in climbers.
cues: Sit on floor with front leg shin parallel to body front, back leg shin behind you
Both hips at 90° — 'square' the position before adding forward lean
Lean slowly over front shin while maintaining a long spine — stop when back rounds
Hold 30-60s per side in each direction (external and internal rotation)
Active version: lift each knee off the floor without using hands — this tests hip strength in range

exercises.name: Max Hang 10s (Hypertrophy)

prescription_defaults.notes: 85-90% intensity. Longer duration for structural/hypertrophic adaptation.

exercises.description: Extended-duration maximum-weight hangs (10 seconds) targeting structural tendon adaptation and finger flexor hypertrophy. The longer hang time shifts the training stimulus from pure neural recruitment toward connective tissue remodeling (López/Eva López long-duration variant).
cues: Choose edge/weight you can hold for exactly 13-14s max
Hang precisely 10 seconds — do not hang to failure
Shoulders engaged and packed, elbows slightly bent
Body completely still — no swinging or kipping
3-minute rest between sets for full phosphocreatine recovery

exercises.name: Campus Board Touches

prescription_defaults.notes: Touch high rung and return. Focus on speed and precision. Contact strength development.

exercises.description: One-arm campus touch — hold bottom rung with both hands, pull up and touch the highest rung possible with one hand using deadpoint technique, return and repeat. Trains maximum unilateral contact strength and explosive reach. (Hörst, Gresham: intermediate-advanced, 5.12+/V6+)
cues: Both hands on low rung, pull up with momentum
Deadpoint the touch: reach at the apex of upward momentum
Touch — don't grab — the high rung, then catch return
Alternate leading hand each rep
Minimum contact time on the catch rung

exercises.name: Campus Max Ladders

prescription_defaults.notes: Advanced. 1-4-7, 1-5-8 patterns. Full body tension. Stop when speed drops. Anderson RCTM / Hörst.

exercises.description: Footless campus laddering with maximum rung spacing — skipping rungs for power. Shifts training emphasis from contact strength to explosive pulling power. (Hörst: larger holds + rung skips = arm power vs small holds + no skips = contact strength)
cues: Larger rungs, skip 1-2 rungs per move
Explosive pull to generate height before placing next hand
Shoulders engaged throughout — never passive hanging
3 sets, 2-3 min rest — stop before form fails
Elite only: do not add weight without 2+ years campus experience

exercises.name: Campus Board Switches

prescription_defaults.notes: Match on rung, rapid hand switches (hand-over-hand). Speed training. Same rung height throughout.

exercises.description: Both-hands simultaneous campus board movement — both hands release and land on new rungs at the same time. Maximum coordination and RFD stimulus. Highest contact strength and power demand of all campus exercises. (Hörst, Gresham — advanced only)
cues: Start hands staggered: one high, one low, shoulder-width apart
Simultaneously release and swap positions in one explosive move
Open-hand grip only — never full crimp on catches
Land with bent elbows to absorb force
Rest 3+ min between sets — CNS demanding

exercises.name: Campus Sprint Endurance

prescription_defaults.notes: Up and down repeatedly for 15-20s. Alactic-aerobic campus capacity. Stop if form breaks.

exercises.description: Campus board arm sprints for alactic-aerobic capacity. Up-and-down the largest rungs as fast as possible for 15-20 seconds. Trains the alactic PCr system to rapidly reload between explosive efforts — the mechanism that allows hard boulderers to do multiple attempts with short rest. High injury risk: warm up thoroughly, stop if shoulder fatigue appears. (Hörst PE protocols; campus endurance progressions)
cues: Largest rungs only: this is not a strength exercise, it is a sprint
Go as fast as possible — each 15s effort is near-max arm speed
If you can't reach the top rung, skip fewer rungs on the next set
Stop immediately at any shoulder elevation or shrugging — campus work demands scapular engagement throughout
120s rest between sets: full PCr recovery before the next all-out sprint

exercises.name: EMOM Bouldering

prescription_defaults.notes: Every Minute On the Minute: start a problem at 0:00, 1:00, 2:00... rest is whatever remains of each minute. Typical problem takes 20-30s. Grade 2-4 below boulder max. 12 problems = 12 min. Reduce grade mid-session to maintain form — EMOM trains capacity, not failure.

exercises.description: Every Minute On the Minute bouldering: one problem per minute for 10-12 rounds. The fixed 60-second clock progressively reduces rest as sessions advance — early rounds feel easy, later rounds increasingly pump. Trains aerobic power and recovery ability at submaximal climbing intensity. Ideal format for building density of hard moves without exceeding anaerobic threshold. (Hörst EMOM; Lattice aerobic power intervals)
cues: Start each problem exactly at the minute mark — use a visible timer
Grade: 2-4 below boulder max. Problems should be high-percentage to avoid failure mid-round
Rest is whatever remains of each 60s — if you're using under 30s per climb, go harder
When round 8-12 starts to feel hard, that's the training stimulus — don't reduce grade unless you'll fail
Progress: 12 rounds → 15 rounds → 1 level harder at 12 rounds

exercises.name: OTM Bouldering (Every 2 Minutes)

prescription_defaults.notes: One problem every 2 minutes: start at 0:00, 2:00, 4:00... 10 problems = 20 min per set. 10 min rest between sets. Grade at or just above flash: harder than EMOM since longer rest allows harder effort. Stop if form breaks. Bechtel OTM protocol.

exercises.description: On The Minute bouldering (Bechtel): 10 problems over 20 minutes, one every 2 minutes, then 10-minute rest. The 2-minute cycle allows harder problems than EMOM while still accumulating training density over the session. Tracks improvement by noting total problems completed per session over the training cycle. Use on a home wall or spray wall where you know the problems well. (Bechtel climbing.com; OTM progression model)
cues: 2-minute cycle: problem starts at 0:00, 2:00, 4:00... rest is whatever remains between problems
Grade: just above or at flash level — harder than EMOM because you have more rest
Know your problems in advance — onsighting during OTM wastes time and breaks flow
If problems are taking >35 seconds, they are too hard: switch to lower grade
Progress: add 1 problem per session, not 1 grade. Volume before intensity.

exercises.name: Linked Boulder Circuit

prescription_defaults.notes: Link 3-5 boulders back-to-back, no rest between. Grade 2-3 below flash. 5 min rest between circuits.

exercises.description: Link 3-5 boulder problems back-to-back without rest between them. Each circuit of 3-5 linked problems constitutes one set. Grade is 2-3 below boulder flash so each individual problem is manageable but accumulated pump over the circuit creates anaerobic lactic stress. Closest to route climbing specificity among all bouldering PE protocols. (Hörst PE protocols; Lattice Boulder Triples pattern)
cues: Choose 3-5 problems you can reliably flash individually — linking is the challenge, not each problem
No rest between problems in a circuit: step off one and onto the next immediately
Grade target: 2-3 below individual flash. By problem 4-5 you should feel significant pump
5 min rest between circuits: this is a minimum. Take more if needed to restore quality
Sets 2-3 will feel much harder than set 1 — that metabolic accumulation is the point

exercises.name: ARC Training Progressive

prescription_defaults.notes: Start at 15 min continuous, build to 30 min week over week. Grade well below onsight. Zero pump target.

exercises.description: Progressive ARC protocol building from 15 min continuous to 30+ min over successive weeks. Ideal first endurance cycle for boulderers transitioning to route training, or returning from injury. Each week add 2-3 minutes per set until 30 min is comfortable. Grade stays fixed — only volume increases. (Lattice progressive load model; Hörst aerobic base programming)
cues: Week 1: 15 min each set. Week 2: 18 min. Week 3: 21 min. Week 4+: continue adding 2-3 min
Grade must stay fixed throughout the progression cycle — never raise grade while building volume
Stop the progression if any pump appears during a set — that signals the grade is creeping up
Keep a timer visible: knowing the remaining time helps pace the effort mentally
300s rest between sets is a minimum — take more if needed to fully recover

exercises.name: Threshold Long Intervals (2:1)

prescription_defaults.notes: 120s climb / 60s rest. Moderate pump OK, deep pump = too hard. RPE 7-8/10. Hörst recommended protocol.

exercises.description: Threshold intervals performed on bouldering wall, spray wall, or board (not limited to routes). Identical timing to threshold_climbing (120s work / 60s rest) but equipment-agnostic — links boulder problems to accumulate pump rather than climbing a single route. Useful when route gym access is unavailable or when working a specific movement pattern. (Hörst 2:1 threshold intervals; Unlevel Edge 7-min variant reference)
cues: Link 3-5 boulder problems continuously for the 120s round — don't stop between problems
Grade of linked problems: 1-2 below boulder onsight individually, but pump accumulates over 120s
RPE 7-8/10 at the end of each set. First 60s easy, last 60s hard — that progression is correct
60s rest: walk, shake out, breathe deeply. Partial recovery is intentional
Same set count and rest structure as threshold_climbing — sessions are interchangeable in programming

exercises.name: Regeneration Climbing

prescription_defaults.notes: Grade 4-6 below onsight. Conversational pace. 20-30 min. Focus on movement quality, not effort.

exercises.description: 20-30 minutes of continuous climbing at grade 4-6 below onsight. Conversational pace throughout. Used as a cooldown exercise at the end of hard sessions, or as a standalone active recovery session 24-36h after maximum effort days. The forearm aerobic system benefits even at very low intensity — there is no minimum threshold to get an aerobic adaptation stimulus. (Hörst submaximal volume; Lattice regeneration protocol)
cues: Grade 4-6 below your lead onsight — you should be able to close your eyes on the holds
Conversational pace: the acid test is whether you can hold a full conversation while climbing
Arms feel light after 10 min: this is blood flow working. The forearms should never build pump
After a hard session: use this to flush lactate and restore forearm blood flow before leaving the gym
Duration flexible: 20 min minimum, but 30+ min gives a stronger aerobic stimulus

exercises.name: Pronator Teres Isometric Hold

prescription_defaults.notes: Hold band resisted pronation at 90° elbow. Light tension, pain-free.

exercises.description: Isometric hold targeting pronator teres to prevent climber's elbow.
cues: Elbow at 90°
Palm up, resist internal rotation
Keep shoulder relaxed

exercises.name: Stick Pronation/Supination Eccentrics

prescription_defaults.notes: Slow eccentric (4-5s) pronation and supination with light dumbbell.

exercises.description: Eccentric rotation for medial epicondylitis prevention.
cues: Slow control on lowering
Neutral wrist
No pain allowed

exercises.name: Heel-Hook Specific Drill

prescription_defaults.notes: Easy problems, focus only on heel placement.

exercises.description: Isolates heel-hook technique on volume terrain.
cues: Active heel pull
Hip close to wall
Relaxed arms

exercises.name: Grip Transitions (Half-Crimp to Open-Hand)

prescription_defaults.notes: Transition mid-hang from half-crimp to open-hand.

exercises.description: Improves grip adaptability and tendon resilience.
cues: Smooth transition
No slip
Shoulders engaged

exercises.name: Wall Slide (Forearm)

prescription_defaults.notes: Forearms against wall at 90°, slide upward without shrugging. 5s up / 5s down.

exercises.description: Forearm wall slide targeting serratus anterior and upward scapular rotation. The most evidence-based shoulder prehab exercise for overhead athletes — validated by JOSPT EMG study (Hardwick et al.). Directly addresses the scapular downward-rotation pattern common in climbers.
cues: Forearms flat on wall, elbows at 90°, shoulder-width apart
Press forearms INTO the wall with constant force throughout
Slide arms upward without shrugging shoulders
Feel shoulder blades spread and rotate outward at the top
Slow and controlled: 5s up, 5s down

exercises.name: Active Finger Curls (Dynamic Tendon Loading)

prescription_defaults.notes: Hang at 50-70% BW on open-hand edge. Small controlled curls at fingertips. Submaximal always.

exercises.description: Dynamic tendon loading via small active curls on hangboard edge. Tyler Nelson (Camp 4 Human Performance) protocol for stimulating tendon adaptation through controlled dynamic loading — distinct from the purely isometric approach of long_duration_hang. Creates different mechanical stimulus for pulley and tendon health.
cues: Load edge at 50-70% bodyweight — use pulley assist if needed
Open-hand grip only, never full crimp for prehab
Small curl movement at fingertips — not a full grip change
Controlled speed in both directions, no snapping
Submaximal: this is health work, stop if any pulley pain

exercises.name: Copenhagen Plank

prescription_defaults.notes: Each side. Regress: bottom knee bent on bench. Progress: dynamic dips from position.

exercises.description: Lateral plank with top foot on a bench, targeting adductors, obliques and lateral hip stabilizers. One of the most effective exercises for the inner thigh/hip complex needed for high-steps, knee-drops and heel hooks on steep terrain. Underused by climbers. (Lattice S&C conditioning; climbing physio literature)
cues: Top foot rests on bench, bottom leg hangs freely — maintain full lateral body line
Drive top hip up to maintain plank position — do not let hips sag
Ear, shoulder, hip, ankle in line when viewed from the side
Feel the adductor of the top leg working actively to maintain position
Both sides equal — do not skip the weaker side

exercises.name: Hangboard Moving Hangs (HMH)

prescription_defaults.notes: 5 min moving / 5 min rest. Feet on floor or box behind hangboard. Move hands continuously between holds. Load controlled by hold size and wall angle. Beginner-friendly — safe for intermediate and below.

exercises.description: Hörst Hangboard Moving Hangs (HMH): feet supported, hands move continuously between holds. Genuinely different from all static/intermittent protocols — 50/50 duty cycle, active movement, load controlled by hold size and foot position. Trains aerobic forearm endurance when below Critical Force, strength-endurance when above. Ideal entry protocol for climbers new to hangboarding: safe, versatile, and home-compatible. (Hörst, Conditioning for Climbers 2008; StrengthClimbing HMH analysis)
cues: Feet on floor or on a box placed 30-60 cm behind the hangboard — this is load control
Move hands between holds every 5-10 seconds: use different grip positions each set
For aerobic endurance: choose a hold where you feel nothing in the forearms after 3 min
For strength-endurance: choose a hold where mild pump builds by 3-4 min
After dismounting: hold arms above heart level for 10s, then shake out slowly

exercises.name: 30/30 Climbing Intervals

prescription_defaults.notes: 6 intervals of 30s all-out / 30s rest = 1 set. 10 min rest between sets. 2-4 sets total (well-conditioned climbers only). RPE 9-10/10 during work. Climb intuitive open-hold style — no set problems. Use smallest holds possible without falling. As you fatigue, move to bigger holds rather than stopping.

exercises.description: Hörst 30/30 intervals: 30 seconds all-out climbing alternating with 30 seconds rest, 6 intervals = 1 round. Patented by Eric Hörst as the elite PE protocol that exhausts alactic power while building aerobic power (to drive PCr recovery) without excessive lactic accumulation. Done on spray walls or system boards — no set problems, climb intuitively at max intensity. Contraindicated early in training cycles; program 2-4 weeks max before performance phase. (Hörst trainingforclimbing.com; Cameron Horst climbing.com)
cues: 30s work: absolute maximum intensity — the smallest holds you can hold without falling
30s rest: shake out below heart level, chalk up, breathe deeply. Time this exactly
6 intervals per round: difficulty escalates. Early rounds easy, rounds 5-6 extremely hard
10 min rest between rounds: PCr system needs full recovery to deliver max quality
Stop if a round is clearly failing before 30s — quality over quantity in every session

exercises.name: Frenchies (Isometric Pull-up Intervals)

prescription_defaults.notes: One Frenchie = pull to top (4s hold) → lower to 90° (4s hold) → lower to 120° (4s hold) → return to dead hang. That is 1 rep. Do as many full reps as possible per set, then rest 5 min. 2-3 sets. Hörst coined term in Flash Training (1994). Stop set when unable to complete a full pull or maintain 4s hold.

exercises.description: Frenchies combine dynamic pull-up strength with isometric lock-offs at three joint angles (top/full lock, 90°, 120°), creating one of the most climbing-specific upper-body strength-endurance exercises available. Named and popularised by Eric Hörst (Flash Training, 1994). The time-under-tension at multiple angles directly mirrors the lock-off demands of hard bouldering and steep sport climbing. Elbow stress is significant — do not perform with existing elbow/medial epicondyle pain. Progress by adding a 4th or 5th lock-off angle per rep or by adding weight.
cues: Rep 1 protocol: pull to chin over bar → hold 4s; lower to dead hang; pull again → lower to 90° → hold 4s; lower to dead hang; pull again → lower to 120° → hold 4s; return to dead hang = 1 rep
Palms facing away (pronated) or toward you (supinated) — both valid, alternate for variety
4-second holds are non-negotiable — shorter holds reduce benefit significantly
Set ends when you can no longer do a complete pull-up OR cannot hold 4 seconds
5 full minutes rest between sets — less rest compromises quality severely
Elbow warning: if lateral or medial elbow pain during holds, stop immediately

exercises.name: Uneven-Grip Pull-up (One-Arm Progression)

prescription_defaults.notes: One hand on bar, other hand grips a sling looped over bar — hands offset 30-60 cm (start with 30 cm). 3 sets × 5 reps each arm, 3 min rest between sets. Increase offset as strength improves. Long-term progression toward one-arm pull-up. Hörst: begin with 12-inch offset, increase when you can do 5 solid reps.

exercises.description: Uneven-grip pull-up progressively loads one arm more than the other by offsetting hand height, bridging between two-arm pull-ups and one-arm pull-ups. Hörst recommends it as the most climbing-specific path to lock-off strength and eventual one-arm pull-up capacity. Use a sling looped over a pull-up bar — high hand on bar (palms-in or out), low hand grips sling with deep two-finger or pinch grip (more climbing-specific). Start with 30 cm offset; as strength improves increase to 60 cm. Alternate arms each set.
cues: High hand on bar, low hand on sling — not the reverse
Focus on pulling with the HIGH hand; low hand assists progressively less
Full range of motion required — dead hang to chin over bar height
Alternate arms each set: do not favour one side
30 cm offset for beginners → 45 cm → 60 cm as a rough progression
To increase climbing specificity: high hand uses palms-away (pronated) grip

exercises.name: 1-on / 1-off Aerobic Intervals (Lattice)

prescription_defaults.notes: 1 min climbing / 1 min rest x 10 rounds = 20 min total. Grade 1-2 below lead onsight. Aim for zero pump — intensity sits just above ARC but below threshold. If pump accumulates by round 6-7, reduce grade next session. Lattice Randall/Torr protocol.

exercises.description: Lattice Training 1-on/1-off aerobic capacity protocol (Tom Randall & Ollie Torr). 10 rounds of 1 min climbing / 1 min rest at 1-2 grades below onsight. Classified by Lattice as aerobic capacity, not power endurance — the grade is the key: low enough to stay aerobic and avoid deep pump. Efficient 20-min format, usable on routes, boulders or spray wall. Bridges the gap between long ARC sessions and threshold intervals. (Lattice Training EpicTV 20-min Endurance Workout; Tom Randall UKC endurance series)
cues: Start every round at the 0:00 and 2:00 marks — use a visible timer
Grade: 1-2 letter grades below your lead onsight. Both work; 2 below is safer aerobically
Round 1-4 should feel almost too easy — that is correct. Do not raise grade
If pump builds by round 6-7, you are too hard: grade down next session
1 min rest: arms below heart level, shake out, breathe. Full but not excessive

exercises.name: Aerobic Pyramid Intervals (1-2-3-4-3-2-1)

prescription_defaults.notes: Pyramid: 1 min on / 1 off → 2/2 → 3/3 → 4/4 → 3/3 → 2/2 → 1/1. 7 rounds total = ~28 min. Grade 2 below redpoint. Aerobic target — avoid pump throughout. Beginners start with just 3 rounds (1-2-3 without descent). Horst pyramid protocol.

exercises.description: Hörst aerobic pyramid: 1-2-3-4-3-2-1 min climbing intervals with equal rest, totalling ~28 min. Grade stays constant throughout (2 below redpoint limit, ~2 below onsight). The ascending rounds build aerobic load progressively; the descending side maintains stimulus while fatigue accumulates. Makes standard ARC sessions more mentally engaging. First-timers should stop at the peak (1-2-3) to avoid excessive volume. (Hörst / Lucie Hanes, trainingforclimbing.com aerobic vs anaerobic article)
cues: Equal work = equal rest at every level: 1/1, 2/2, 3/3, 4/4...
Grade is fixed throughout the pyramid — do not increase as rounds get longer
4-min rounds should feel sustainably hard but never cause full pump
Beginners: do 1-2-3 only (no descent) — ~12 min total, build from there
After the session: arms felt lightly worked, not pumped. If pumped, grade too hard

exercises.name: Hip Flexor Couch Stretch (Psoas / Quad)

prescription_defaults.notes: 2 sets × 90s per side. Rear foot elevated on couch/bench/wall, front foot on floor in lunge position. Hips drive forward gently. Hörst specifically recommends regular psoas stretching for climbers who sit for extended periods.

exercises.description: The couch stretch is the gold standard for hip flexor (psoas, iliacus, rectus femoris) lengthening. Rear foot elevated on a couch or wall with front foot in a low lunge position. Critically missing from most climbers' routines despite hip flexor shortness being endemic — long periods of sitting and lack of hip extension in climbing both shorten hip flexors, which restricts drop-knee range, contributes to anterior pelvic tilt, and limits high-step reach. Hörst recommends regular hip flexor stretching. 90s minimum hold required for meaningful connective tissue adaptation.
cues: Back knee on floor, back foot elevated on couch/bench/wall at hip height or above
Front foot on floor, front shin vertical (knee over ankle)
Drive hips FORWARD and DOWN — the stretch is felt in the front of the elevated-leg hip
Upright torso: do not lean forward to 'cheat' the stretch — keep chest up
Hold 90s minimum per side — 30s holds produce negligible adaptation in hip flexors
After: squeeze glute of stretched leg to reinforce hip extension pattern

exercises.name: Lat and Overhead Flexibility Stretch

prescription_defaults.notes: 2 sets × 60s per side. Doorframe overhead reach or hanging lat stretch (passive dead hang with bent knees to decompress). Lat tightness restricts overhead reach and shoulder overhead press range — common in climbers.

exercises.description: Latissimus dorsi and overhead shoulder flexibility stretch. The lats are heavily loaded during pulling and often shortened in climbers, restricting overhead shoulder range and contributing to internal rotation. Two options: (1) hanging lat stretch — passive dead hang with slightly bent knees, allow shoulders to fully decompress; (2) doorframe/pole reach — one arm overhead gripping a frame, lateral lean away from the arm. Also targets the long head of triceps in the overhead position. Hörst includes lat stretching in post-session recovery protocols in Training for Climbing.
cues: Option A (hanging): dead hang from bar with slightly bent knees, shoulders fully relaxed — 45-60s
Option B (doorframe): one hand overhead on doorframe, opposite hip pushed away from the frame — side-stretch feeling
Option C (kneeling): kneeling at a couch/box, one arm extended forward, drop chest toward floor
Hold still — do not swing or rotate during the stretch
Breathe into the stretched side: feel the ribs expand on the inhale
Option A note: fingers and pulleys take load — avoid if fingers are injured; use Option B or C instead
